trusts.exp: Trustees have a right to be indemnified for properly incurred expenses.

trusts.q: 'Impounding' allows the court to use a beneficiary's interest to cover a breach.
trusts.exp: s.62 TA 1925; if the beneficiary instigated or consented to the breach.

trusts.q: 'Exemption Clause' can exclude liability for fraudulent breaches of trust.
trusts.exp: Armitage v Nurse; cannot exclude liability for fraud/dishonesty.

trusts.q: 'Wilful Default' means a trustee is liable only for intentional breaches.
trusts.exp: Includes conscious negligence or recklessness, not just intent.

trusts.q: 'Statutory Duty of Care' is found in s.1 Trustee Act 2000.
trusts.exp: Requires reasonable care and skill, considering special knowledge.

trusts.q: 'Passive Trustee' is one who leaves administration to a co-trustee.
trusts.exp: Still liable for breaches; trustees must act jointly.

trusts.q: 'Breach of Trust' is any act or omission contrary to trustee duties.
trusts.exp: Includes unauthorized acts and failure to meet the standard of care.

trusts.q: 'Benjamin Order' allows trustees to distribute when a beneficiary is missing.
trusts.exp: Presumes the beneficiary is dead for distribution purposes.

trusts.q: A trustee sells trust property to a company in which they are the sole shareholder. This transaction is automatically void.
trusts.exp: Self-dealing transactions are voidable by the beneficiaries, not automatically void.

trusts.q: A trustee can purchase a beneficiary's equitable interest if they can prove they acted fairly and honestly.
trusts.exp: This is the 'Fair-Dealing' rule; the transaction is valid if the trustee proves fairness and full disclosure.

trusts.q: A solicitor trustee can keep the interest earned on client money held in a general client account.
trusts.exp: Brown v IRC; interest earned on client money belongs to the client (principal), not the solicitor (fiduciary).

trusts.q: A trustee appointed as a company director by virtue of their shareholding can keep the director's fees.
trusts.exp: Re Macadam; they must account to the trust for remuneration received by virtue of their trustee position.

trusts.q: The strict rule in Keech v Sandford applies even if the landlord refuses to renew the lease to the trust.
trusts.exp: The trustee cannot take the renewal personally, even if it is impossible for the trust to do so.

trusts.q: Beneficiaries can elect between a personal and a proprietary remedy for a breach of the no-profit rule.
trusts.exp: FHR European Ventures; principals can choose an account of profits or a constructive trust.

trusts.q: Dishonesty in 'dishonest assistance' is determined purely by the defendant's subjective beliefs.
trusts.exp: Ivey v Genting Casinos; the test is objective (standard of ordinary decent people) based on subjective knowledge.

trusts.q: A stranger can be liable for knowing receipt even if they no longer hold the property.
trusts.exp: Knowing receipt is a personal claim; liability remains even if the assets are dissipated (unlike a proprietary claim).

trusts.q: For dishonest assistance, the trustee must also have been dishonest.
trusts.exp: Royal Brunei Airlines v Tan; the assistant's dishonesty is sufficient, regardless of the trustee's state of mind.

trusts.q: A recipient of trust property is liable for knowing receipt if they have 'constructive notice' only.
trusts.exp: BCCI v Akindele; the test is 'unconscionability', which generally requires more than mere constructive notice.

trusts.q: In Boardman v Phipps, the solicitor was liable because he acted with bad faith.
trusts.exp: He acted in good faith but was still liable for the profit because he used information acquired as a fiduciary.

trusts.q: A trustee can keep director's fees if the trust deed expressly authorizes it.
trusts.exp: Re Llewellin's Will Trusts; the trust instrument can modify the strict no-profit rule.

trusts.q: Assistance in a dishonest assistance claim must be more than minimal.
trusts.exp: Ultraframe (UK) Ltd v Fielding; the assistance must make the breach easier to commit.

trusts.q: A bank receiving money into an overdrawn account receives it beneficially for knowing receipt purposes.
trusts.exp: The bank benefits by the reduction of the debt, unlike a credit account where it holds as agent/debtor.

trusts.q: A fiduciary can avoid liability for conflict of interest by obtaining the consent of their co-fiduciaries.
trusts.exp: Consent must come from the *principals* (beneficiaries), not co-trustees.

trusts.q: A dishonest assistant is always liable for the profits they make from the breach.
trusts.exp: Novoship v Mikhaylyuk; the court has discretion to withhold the remedy if disproportionate.

trusts.q: Registration of land wipes out a beneficiary's interest against a purchaser without notice.
trusts.exp: s.29 LRA 2002; a purchaser for value takes free of unregistered equitable interests (unless overriding).

trusts.q: Knowing receipt requires the defendant to have received the property beneficially.
trusts.exp: Receipt in a ministerial capacity (e.g., as an agent) is insufficient for knowing receipt.

trusts.q: The 'self-dealing' rule applies when a trustee sells their own property to the trust.
trusts.exp: It applies to both purchases from and sales to the trust by the trustee.

trusts.q: A fiduciary who takes a bribe holds it on constructive trust for their principal.
trusts.exp: FHR European Ventures; bribes are treated as the property of the principal.

trusts.q: Fully informed consent for a breach of fiduciary duty must be obtained from the court.
trusts.exp: Consent can be given by the beneficiaries if they are all sui juris and fully informed.

trusts.q: A dishonest assistant is liable for the full loss caused by the breach of trust.
trusts.exp: They are jointly and severally liable with the trustee for the loss.

trusts.q: The Baden scale of knowledge is irrelevant to modern knowing receipt claims.
trusts.exp: While 'unconscionability' is the test, the Baden categories help determine what makes conduct unconscionable.

trusts.q: A trustee can compete with the trust business if the trust deed is silent.
trusts.exp: Re Thomson; fiduciaries generally cannot enter into competition with the trust business.

trusts.q: Rescission is available for self-dealing even if the property has been sold to a bona fide purchaser.
trusts.exp: Rescission is barred if third-party rights have intervened (bona fide purchaser).

trusts.q: A 'Fiduciary' is a person who owes duties of loyalty and good faith.
trusts.exp: Examples include trustees, solicitors, and agents.

trusts.q: 'Self-Dealing' refers to a trustee transacting with the trust.
trusts.exp: Buying from or selling to the trust is prohibited without authority.

trusts.q: 'Fair-Dealing' refers to a trustee transacting with a beneficiary.
trusts.exp: Buying the beneficiary's interest is permitted subject to strict fairness rules.

trusts.q: The 'No-Conflict Rule' prevents a fiduciary from putting personal interests ahead of their duty.
trusts.exp: A core fiduciary obligation to avoid conflict between duty and interest.

trusts.q: The 'No-Profit Rule' prevents a fiduciary from making unauthorized gains from their position.
trusts.exp: Fiduciaries must account for any unauthorized profit made by virtue of their office.

trusts.q: 'Dishonest Assistance' is a receipt-based claim.
trusts.exp: It is a fault-based accessory liability claim (secondary liability for breach).

trusts.q: 'Knowing Receipt' is a claim against someone who receives trust property with unconscionable knowledge.
trusts.exp: A personal claim for the value of property received in breach of trust.

trusts.q: 'Accessory Liability' requires the defendant to have received trust property.
trusts.exp: It requires assistance in the breach, not necessarily receipt of property.

trusts.q: 'Unconscionability' is the key test for liability in knowing receipt.
trusts.exp: BCCI v Akindele; the recipient's state of knowledge must make retention unconscionable.

trusts.q: A 'Constructive Trust' can be a proprietary remedy for breach of fiduciary duty.
trusts.exp: The court can declare that illicit profits are held on constructive trust.

trusts.q: 'Account of Profits' is a proprietary claim.
trusts.exp: It is a personal claim for the value of the profit made.

trusts.q: 'Voidable' means a transaction is automatically invalid.
trusts.exp: It means the transaction is valid until set aside (rescinded) by the beneficiaries.

trusts.q: 'Rescission' puts the parties back in the position they were in before the transaction.
trusts.exp: It unwinds the transaction (restitutio in integrum).

trusts.q: A 'Stranger' to the trust is anyone other than a trustee or beneficiary.
trusts.exp: Third parties who may become liable for assisting or receiving from a breach.

trusts.q: 'Vicarious Liability' makes a partner liable for another partner's dishonest assistance.
trusts.exp: Partnerships can be vicariously liable for the wrongful acts of a partner in the ordinary course of business.

trusts.q: 'Tracing' is the process of identifying a new asset as a substitute for the old.
trusts.exp: Foskett v McKeown; distinct from following the same asset.

trusts.q: 'Following' is the process of tracking the same asset as it moves hands.
trusts.exp: Foskett v McKeown; locating the original asset itself.

trusts.q: 'Bona Fide Purchaser' (Equity's Darling) takes property free of equitable interests.
trusts.exp: Must be for value and without notice (actual, constructive, or imputed).

trusts.q: 'Ministerial Capacity' refers to holding property as an agent without beneficial interest.
trusts.exp: Agents receiving funds for a principal do not typically incur knowing receipt liability.

trusts.q: 'Joint and Several Liability' means each wrongdoer is liable for the entire loss.
trusts.exp: The claimant can sue any one of them for the full amount.

trusts.q: 'Solicitor-Client' is a recognized fiduciary relationship.
trusts.exp: Solicitors owe fiduciary duties of loyalty to their clients.

trusts.q: 'Director-Company' is a recognized fiduciary relationship.
trusts.exp: Directors act as fiduciaries for the company.

trusts.q: The 'Baden Scale' categorizes degrees of knowledge.
trusts.exp: Used to analyze the mental state for knowing receipt (actual knowledge to constructive notice).

trusts.q: 'Strict Liability' means liability arises regardless of fault or dishonesty.
trusts.exp: Trustees are strictly liable for misapplication of assets (breach of trust), unlike accessories.

trusts.q: An 'Injunction' is a court order to do or stop doing a specific act.
trusts.exp: An equitable remedy often used to prevent a breach of confidence or duty.

trusts.q: Beneficiaries can trace into the hands of a bona fide purchaser for value without notice.
trusts.exp: Foskett v McKeown; a BFP takes the property free of equitable interests, extinguishing the proprietary claim.

trusts.q: The rule in Clayton's Case ('first in, first out') is always applied to innocent mixtures in current accounts.
trusts.exp: Barlow Clowes v Vaughan; it can be disapplied if contrary to intention, unjust, or impracticable.

trusts.q: A beneficiary can claim a proportionate share of an asset bought with a mixed fund (trustee + trust money).
trusts.exp: Foskett v McKeown; beneficiaries can choose between a proportionate share or a lien.

trusts.q: If a trustee dissipates mixed funds (trustee + trust), the dissipated money is presumed to be the trustee's.
trusts.exp: Re Hallett's Estate; the trustee is presumed to spend their own money first to preserve trust funds.

trusts.q: In an innocent mixture (two trusts), losses are shared rateably (pari passu).
trusts.exp: Re Diplock; innocent contributors share the remaining pool in proportion to their contributions.

trusts.q: Beneficiaries can use 'cherry picking' against the unsecured creditors of an insolvent trustee.
trusts.exp: Shalson v Russo; cherry picking is allowed against the trustee personally, but not to prejudice other innocent creditors.

trusts.q: Subrogation allows a beneficiary to step into the shoes of a secured creditor if trust money paid off the debt.
trusts.exp: Boscawen v Bajwa; revives the extinguished security for the benefit of the trust.

trusts.q: Tracing is possible into an asset purchased by an innocent volunteer.
trusts.exp: Re Diplock; volunteers (who paid no value) take property subject to equitable interests.

trusts.q: Backward tracing (into an asset bought before the misappropriation) is never permitted.
trusts.exp: Brazil v Durant; permitted if there is a close causal link/coordinated scheme.

trusts.q: If a trustee buys an asset with trust money and it increases in value, the beneficiary can claim the profit.
trusts.exp: Foskett v McKeown; beneficiaries can elect to take the beneficial ownership of the asset.

trusts.q: Common law tracing allows tracing into a mixed bank account.
trusts.exp: Agip (Africa) Ltd v Jackson; mixing defeats common law tracing (which requires clean physical substitution).

trusts.q: An equitable lien allows the beneficiary to take ownership of the asset.
trusts.exp: A lien is a security interest (right to sell and recover sum), not ownership.

trusts.q: The 'Lowest Intermediate Balance' rule limits tracing claims into a mixed account.
trusts.exp: Roscoe v Winder; the claim is limited to the lowest balance in the account after the trust money was deposited.

trusts.q: Re Oatway allows beneficiaries to trace into assets bought first if the remaining balance is dissipated.
trusts.exp: Reverses the Hallett presumption if necessary to prevent injustice to the beneficiaries.

trusts.q: Proprietary claims are available against a knowing recipient who has dissipated the assets.
trusts.exp: If assets are dissipated, there is no property to claim; only a personal claim remains.

trusts.q: The Rolling Charge method is the standard approach for innocent mixtures in current accounts.
trusts.exp: While theoretically fairer, it is complex/expensive; Pari Passu (ex post facto) is more commonly applied (Barlow Clowes).

trusts.q: A fiduciary relationship is required for equitable tracing.
trusts.exp: Re Diplock; a pre-existing fiduciary relationship (or equitable interest) is a prerequisite.

trusts.q: Beneficiaries can trace into money paid to a bank to reduce an overdraft.
trusts.exp: Unless the bank had notice (knowing receipt), the money is dissipated (pay off debt) and cannot be traced.

trusts.q: Change of position is a defense to a proprietary claim.
trusts.exp: It is a defense to a personal claim (e.g., in Re Diplock restitution), not a proprietary one.

trusts.q: If trust money is used to improve an innocent volunteer's land, the beneficiary gets a share of the land.
trusts.exp: Re Diplock; generally no remedy (inequitable to force sale), or at most a lien for the value added.

trusts.q: Personal claims in Re Diplock are limited to the amount of the overpayment.
trusts.exp: Beneficiaries can recover the sum wrongly paid, subject to defenses.

trusts.q: A trustee can assert their own claim to mixed funds before the beneficiaries are satisfied.
trusts.exp: The trustee's interest is subordinated to the beneficiaries' interest.

trusts.q: Subrogation confers the same priority as the original mortgage.
trusts.exp: The beneficiary steps into the lender's shoes, retaining the priority of the paid-off charge.

trusts.q: Following is the process of tracking the value into a new asset.
trusts.exp: Following tracks the *same* asset; Tracing tracks the value into a *substitute*.

trusts.q: Proprietary claims are affected by the trustee's insolvency.
trusts.exp: They give priority over unsecured creditors, 'ringfencing' the asset from insolvency.

trusts.q: 'Tracing' identifies a new asset as a substitute for the old.
trusts.exp: Foskett v McKeown; distinct from following the same asset.

trusts.q: 'Following' tracks the same asset as it moves from hand to hand.
trusts.exp: Foskett v McKeown; locating the original asset itself.

trusts.q: 'Claiming' is the assertion of rights after tracing or following.
trusts.exp: The legal process of recovering the asset or value based on the identification.

trusts.q: 'Clean Substitution' occurs when trust money is used exclusively to buy an asset.
trusts.exp: No mixing with other funds; the asset is the direct product.

trusts.q: 'Mixed Fund' contains money from more than one source.
trusts.exp: E.g., Trust money mixed with Trustee's own money.

trusts.q: 'Wrongful Mixture' involves mixing trust money with the trustee's own money.
trusts.exp: The trustee is the wrongdoer.

trusts.q: 'Innocent Mixture' involves mixing funds from two innocent parties.
trusts.exp: E.g., Two trust funds mixed by a trustee, or trust money mixed by an innocent volunteer.

trusts.q: 'Equitable Lien' is a right to take possession of property.
trusts.exp: It is a charge/security over property to secure a debt, not a right to possession/ownership.

trusts.q: 'Subrogation' means replacing one creditor with another.
trusts.exp: A remedy where the claimant 'steps into the shoes' of a paid-off creditor.

trusts.q: 'Bona Fide Purchaser' takes property free of equitable interests.
trusts.exp: Equity's Darling; must be for value and without notice.

trusts.q: 'Dissipation' means the asset has been destroyed or consumed.
trusts.exp: E.g., spent on a holiday or dinner; tracing generally ends here.

trusts.q: 'Falsification' requires the trustee to restore the trust fund.
trusts.exp: Used for unauthorized misapplication; treats the disbursement as if it never happened.

trusts.q: 'Surcharging' addresses a shortfall in the trust fund caused by negligence.
trusts.exp: Used for breaches of duty (e.g., poor investment); compensation for what the fund *should* be worth.

trusts.q: 'Lowest Intermediate Balance' limits the claim to the lowest amount in the account.
trusts.exp: Prevents tracing into funds deposited *after* the trust money was spent.

trusts.q: 'Clayton's Case' applies the 'First In, First Out' rule.
trusts.exp: Traditional rule for current accounts, often disapplied in favor of pari passu.

trusts.q: 'Pari Passu' means sharing proportionately.
trusts.exp: Assets are shared rateably according to contributions.

trusts.q: 'Rolling Charge' calculates shares at the time of each withdrawal.
trusts.exp: A dynamic method of apportionment, theoretically fairer but complex.

trusts.q: 'Backward Tracing' traces into an asset bought on credit before trust money was used.
trusts.exp: Tracing into the asset paid for by the misappropriated funds.

trusts.q: 'Swollen Assets Theory' suggests a trust exists if the estate is increased by the misappropriation.
trusts.exp: Often rejected in English law; proprietary claims require identification of specific assets.

trusts.q: 'Change of Position' is a defense for an innocent volunteer who spent the money.
trusts.exp: Lipkin Gorman v Karpnale; inequitable to require repayment if they changed position in reliance.

trusts.q: 'Volunteer' is someone who provides no consideration.
trusts.exp: A recipient of a gift.

trusts.q: 'Equity's Darling' refers to the Bona Fide Purchaser for Value Without Notice.
trusts.exp: The absolute defense against equitable proprietary claims.

trusts.q: 'Proprietary Remedy' gives rights in the property itself.
trusts.exp: As opposed to a personal remedy (debt).

trusts.q: 'Personal Remedy' is a claim against the defendant personally.
trusts.exp: Does not attach to specific property; vulnerable to insolvency.

trusts.q: 'Notice' includes actual, constructive, and imputed knowledge.
trusts.exp: Relevant for determining if a purchaser is bona fide.

trusts.q: A trust of land can be validly declared orally.
trusts.exp: s.53(1)(b) LPA 1925; a declaration of trust respecting land must be manifested and proved in signed writing.

trusts.q: The lack of formalities under s.53(1)(b) renders a trust of land void.
trusts.exp: s.53(1)(b) is an evidential requirement; non-compliance renders the trust unenforceable, not void.

trusts.q: If a trust fails for uncertainty of objects, the property results back to the settlor.
trusts.exp: Automatic resulting trust; if the beneficial interest is not effectively disposed of, it returns to the settlor.

trusts.q: A trust of 'the bulk of my estate' is valid.
trusts.exp: Palmer v Simmonds; 'bulk' is linguistically uncertain and fails for lack of certainty of subject matter.

trusts.q: In Paul v Constance, the words 'the money is as much yours as mine' created a trust.
trusts.exp: The court found sufficient intention to create a trust despite the lack of technical language.

trusts.q: A trust of 50 shares from a holding of 950 identical shares requires segregation.
trusts.exp: Hunter v Moss; intangible fungible assets do not require segregation for certainty of subject matter.

trusts.q: A trust of 50 bottles of wine from a larger stock requires segregation.
trusts.exp: Re London Wine; tangible assets must be segregated to be identifiable.

trusts.q: Precatory words like 'in full confidence' impose a binding trust obligation.
trusts.exp: Re Adams and Kensington Vestry; precatory words usually create a moral obligation, not a legal trust.

trusts.q: A trust of 'reasonable income' is void for uncertainty.
trusts.exp: Re Golay's Will Trusts; 'reasonable' is an objective yardstick that the court can quantify.

trusts.q: If a self-declaration of trust fails for uncertainty of objects, the settlor holds the property on resulting trust.
trusts.exp: If a self-declaration fails, the settlor simply remains the absolute owner; no trust is created.

trusts.q: A testamentary trust must comply with s.9 Wills Act 1837.
trusts.exp: To be valid, a will (and trusts within it) must be in writing, signed, and witnessed by two people.

trusts.q: The 'Is/Is Not' test applies to fixed trusts.
trusts.exp: Fixed trusts require a 'complete list' of beneficiaries (conceptual and evidential certainty).

trusts.q: The 'Is/Is Not' test applies to discretionary trusts.
trusts.exp: McPhail v Doulton; trustees must be able to say if any given individual is or is not a member of the class.

trusts.q: Administrative unworkability can invalidate a fiduciary power.
trusts.exp: Re Manisty's Settlement; unworkability invalidates discretionary trusts but not powers.

trusts.q: A trust for 'friends' is conceptually certain.
trusts.exp: Re Barlow's WT; 'friends' is conceptually uncertain for a trust (though valid for a condition precedent).

trusts.q: Evidential uncertainty renders a discretionary trust void under Sachs LJ's approach in Re Baden (No 2).
trusts.exp: Sachs LJ held that claimants must prove they are in the class; otherwise, they are treated as outside.

trusts.q: Segregating funds into a separate bank account is conclusive evidence of an intention to create a trust.
trusts.exp: Re Kayford; it is strong evidence but not conclusive; intention is ascertained from all circumstances.

trusts.q: If a trust fails for uncertainty of intention in a transfer, the transferee takes the property beneficially.
trusts.exp: Lassence v Tierney; if the trust obligation is not binding, the absolute gift takes effect.

trusts.q: A power of appointment requires the donee to distribute the property.
trusts.exp: A power is discretionary; the donee can choose not to exercise it (unlike a trust).

trusts.q: A trust for 'relatives' is conceptually certain.
trusts.exp: Re Baden (No 2); 'relatives' means 'descendants from a common ancestor' (or next of kin).

trusts.q: The beneficiary principle allows a trust to exist for a purpose.
trusts.exp: Generally, a trust must have human beneficiaries (exceptions: charitable/Endacott trusts).

trusts.q: A settlor can also be a beneficiary of the trust they create.
trusts.exp: A settlor can transfer property to trustees to hold for themselves (e.g., life interest).

trusts.q: If a trust fails for uncertainty of subject matter (beneficial share), the property results to the settlor.
trusts.exp: Boyce v Boyce; if the shares are uncertain, the trust fails and results back.

trusts.q: A trust of 'the remaining part of what is left' is certain if the primary gift allows capital dissipation.
trusts.exp: Sprange v Barnard; if the first recipient can use up the capital, the remainder is uncertain.

trusts.q: A gift-over in default of appointment indicates a power of appointment.
trusts.exp: It shows the settlor envisaged the power might not be exercised.

trusts.q: A 'Settlor' is the person who creates the trust.
trusts.exp: They transfer property to trustees or declare themselves trustee.

trusts.q: A 'Trustee' holds the equitable title to trust property.
trusts.exp: The trustee holds the legal title; the beneficiary holds the equitable title.

trusts.q: A 'Beneficiary' (or Object) is the person for whose benefit the property is held.
trusts.exp: They hold the equitable/beneficial interest and can enforce the trust.

trusts.q: An 'Express Trust' is one created intentionally by the settlor.
trusts.exp: It is created by words or conduct manifesting an intention to create a trust.

trusts.q: An 'Inter Vivos' trust is created by a will.
trusts.exp: 'Inter vivos' means 'during lifetime'; trusts created by will are 'Testamentary'.

trusts.q: A 'Testamentary Trust' takes effect upon the death of the testator.
trusts.exp: It is created via a valid will and operates only after death.

trusts.q: A 'Bare Trust' involves trustees with active management duties.
trusts.exp: In a bare trust, the trustee's only duty is to hold the property and transfer it as directed.

trusts.q: A 'Fixed Trust' gives the trustee discretion over who benefits.
trusts.exp: In a fixed trust, the beneficiaries and their shares are determined by the settlor.

trusts.q: A 'Discretionary Trust' allows trustees to decide how to distribute income/capital.
trusts.exp: Trustees have discretion over which objects benefit and in what proportions.

trusts.q: A 'Resulting Trust' arises based on the presumed intention of the transferor.
trusts.exp: It is an implied trust where beneficial interest 'results' back to the transferor.

trusts.q: A 'Constructive Trust' is imposed by the court to prevent unconscionable conduct.
trusts.exp: It arises by operation of law, regardless of the parties' intentions.

trusts.q: 'Fungible' assets are identical and interchangeable.
trusts.exp: Examples include shares of the same class or money; specific identification is not needed.

trusts.q: A 'Chose in Action' is a tangible physical object.
trusts.exp: It is an intangible right enforceable by legal action (e.g., a debt, shares, IP).

trusts.q: A 'Chattel' is a personal possession or movable property.
trusts.exp: Examples include jewelry, furniture, or cars (tangible personal property).

trusts.q: The 'Three Certainties' are Intention, Subject Matter, and Objects.
trusts.exp: Knight v Knight; all three must be present for a valid express trust.

trusts.q: 'Legal Title' represents the formal ownership of the asset.
trusts.exp: It allows the holder to deal with the property at law (e.g., sell it).

trusts.q: 'Equitable Title' represents the right to enjoy the benefit of the asset.
trusts.exp: It is the beneficial interest enforced by equity against the trustee.

trusts.q: A 'Fiduciary' owes a duty of single-minded loyalty to their principal.
trusts.exp: They must not put themselves in a position of conflict or make unauthorized profits.

trusts.q: The 'Beneficiary Principle' states that a trust must have a human beneficiary.
trusts.exp: Someone must be able to enforce the trust (exceptions apply for charities).

trusts.q: 'Precatory Words' express a hope or wish rather than a command.
trusts.exp: Words like 'hope', 'desire', or 'confidence' usually fail to create a trust.

trusts.q: A 'Power of Appointment' compels the holder to distribute property.
trusts.exp: A power gives discretion to distribute but does not compel it (unlike a discretionary trust).

trusts.q: 'Saunders v Vautier' rights allow adult beneficiaries to collapse the trust.
trusts.exp: Beneficiaries who are sui juris and absolutely entitled can direct the transfer of legal title.

trusts.q: The 'Perpetuity Period' limits the duration of a trust.
trusts.exp: It prevents property from being tied up in trust indefinitely.

trusts.q: A 'Volunteer' in equity is someone who has provided consideration.
trusts.exp: A volunteer is someone who has NOT provided consideration.

trusts.q: 'Certainty of Subject Matter' requires identification of the trust property and beneficial interest.
trusts.exp: Both the asset and the share must be certain.

trusts.q: A trust for 'the relief of poverty' fails if it does not benefit the public.
trusts.exp: Dingle v Turner; trusts for the relief of poverty are an exception to the strict public benefit rule (personal nexus allowed).

trusts.q: A trust for 'the advancement of religion' is automatically charitable.
trusts.exp: It must also satisfy the public benefit requirement (demonstrable benefit to the public).

trusts.q: A non-charitable purpose trust for 'a useful memorial to myself' is valid.
trusts.exp: Re Endacott; too vague and outside the specific exceptions (monuments/graves/animals/masses).

trusts.q: A trust to maintain a specific animal (e.g., a pet dog) can be valid as a non-charitable purpose trust.
trusts.exp: Re Dean; a recognized Endacott exception, provided it complies with perpetuity rules.

trusts.q: A trust for political purposes (e.g., changing the law) can be charitable.
trusts.exp: McGovern v AG; political purposes are not charitable (courts cannot judge if changing the law is beneficial).

trusts.q: The maintenance of a private tomb can be a valid charitable purpose.
trusts.exp: It is a private purpose (Re Hooper), unless part of the fabric of a church (advancement of religion).

trusts.q: Non-charitable purpose trusts are subject to the rule against inalienability.
trusts.exp: They must be limited to a perpetuity period (usually 21 years) or they are void.

trusts.q: A trust for 'the education of my children' is charitable.
trusts.exp: Oppenheim v Tobacco Securities Trust; fails the public benefit test due to the personal nexus.

trusts.q: Cy-près can be applied if a non-charitable purpose trust fails.
trusts.exp: Cy-près applies only to charitable trusts; failed non-charitable trusts result back to the settlor.

trusts.q: A trust for the advancement of sport is charitable only if it promotes health.
trusts.exp: s.3(2)(d) Charities Act 2011; sport involves physical or mental skill/exertion promoting health.

trusts.q: A trust for the saying of private masses is a valid charitable trust.
trusts.exp: Gilmour v Coats; private masses lack public benefit, though they may be valid non-charitable trusts (Re Hetherington).

trusts.q: The 'personal nexus' test disqualifies trusts for the relief of poverty.
trusts.exp: Re Scarisbrick; poverty trusts are the exception where a personal nexus (e.g., 'poor relations') does not fail charity.

trusts.q: A trust for the 'abolition of vivisection' is charitable.
trusts.exp: National Anti-Vivisection Society v IRC; political purpose (changing law) and public benefit outweighed by detriment to science.

trusts.q: The perpetuity period for a non-charitable purpose trust can be 'as long as the law allows'.
trusts.exp: Though vague, courts often interpret this as 21 years (common law period).

trusts.q: A trust for the advancement of human rights is a recognized charitable head.
trusts.exp: s.3(1)(h) Charities Act 2011; includes conflict resolution and equality.

trusts.q: A charitable trust can charge fees for its services.
trusts.exp: Independent Schools Council; provided the poor are not entirely excluded (more than token benefit).

trusts.q: A trust for the 'preservation of the environment' is charitable.
trusts.exp: s.3(1)(i) Charities Act 2011; advancement of environmental protection is a head of charity.

trusts.q: If a charitable purpose fails initially, the funds are always applied cy-près.
trusts.exp: Only if there is a 'general charitable intention'; otherwise, it results back to the donor (Re Good).

trusts.q: A trust for 'the working classes' is a valid trust for the relief of poverty.
trusts.exp: Re Sanders' WT; 'working class' does not necessarily mean 'poor' or 'impoverished'.

trusts.q: The promotion of ethical standards in business is a charitable purpose.
trusts.exp: IRC v Oldham TEC; promoting industry/commerce for private gain is not charitable unless for public benefit.

trusts.q: A trust for 'the 40-letter alphabet' was charitable.
trusts.exp: Re Shaw; mere increase in knowledge without education/teaching is not charitable.

trusts.q: A non-charitable purpose trust can be enforced by the Attorney General.
trusts.exp: The AG enforces charitable trusts; non-charitable ones are unenforceable (imperfect obligation).

trusts.q: A trust for 'my old regiment' to buy sports gear is charitable.
trusts.exp: Re Gray; promotion of efficiency of the armed forces is a charitable head.

trusts.q: A trust for 'benevolent purposes' is charitable.
trusts.exp: Chichester Diocesan Fund v Simpson; 'benevolent' is broader than 'charitable', so the trust fails for uncertainty.

trusts.q: A trust for the 'welfare of cats' is charitable.
trusts.exp: Re Moss; advancement of animal welfare is charitable (benefit to human morality).

trusts.q: 'Charitable Purpose Trust' must be for the public benefit.
trusts.exp: s.2 Charities Act 2011; defined by purpose (s.3) and public benefit (s.4).

trusts.q: 'Non-Charitable Purpose Trust' is generally void.
trusts.exp: Re Endacott; violates the beneficiary principle (except for specific anomalies).

trusts.q: 'Beneficiary Principle' requires a trust to have ascertainable beneficiaries.
trusts.exp: Morice v Bishop of Durham; someone must be able to enforce the trust.

trusts.q: 'Cy-près Doctrine' allows charitable funds to be redirected.
trusts.exp: If the original purpose fails, funds go to a similar charitable purpose (closest match).

trusts.q: 'Public Benefit' has two limbs: identifiable benefit and section of the public.
trusts.exp: Independent Schools Council; benefit must be clear and not restricted to a private class.

trusts.q: 'Personal Nexus' refers to a relationship linking beneficiaries (e.g., employees).
trusts.exp: Oppenheim; a personal link to a settlor/employer usually negates the 'public' element.

trusts.q: 'Endacott Exceptions' are valid non-charitable purpose trusts.
trusts.exp: Anomalous categories: animals, graves/monuments, private masses.

trusts.q: 'Perpetuity Rule' for non-charitable trusts is the rule against inalienability.
trusts.exp: The trust must end within the perpetuity period (21 years).

trusts.q: 'Trust of Imperfect Obligation' is a valid but unenforceable trust.
trusts.exp: E.g., Endacott exceptions; the trustee can perform it, but no one can compel them.

trusts.q: 'Pettingall Order' allows the court to ensure a purpose trust is carried out.
trusts.exp: The trustee undertakes to perform the trust, allowing the residuary legatee to sue if they don't.

trusts.q: 'Charity Commission' is the regulator for charities in England and Wales.
trusts.exp: Registers and regulates charities; ensures compliance.

trusts.q: 'Advancement of Education' includes research only if it is disseminated.
trusts.exp: Re Hopkins; research must be communicable/of educational value to be charitable.

trusts.q: 'Advancement of Religion' requires belief in a supreme being.
trusts.exp: s.3(2)(a) Charities Act 2011; includes religions without a god (e.g., Buddhism).

trusts.q: 'Wholly and Exclusively' means a trust cannot have mixed charitable/non-charitable purposes.
trusts.exp: Unless the non-charitable part is incidental, the trust fails as a charity.

trusts.q: 'Political Purpose' includes campaigning for a change in the law.
trusts.exp: Not charitable; courts must remain neutral on whether changing the law is beneficial.

trusts.q: 'General Charitable Intention' is required for cy-près on initial failure.
trusts.exp: Shows the donor wanted to give to charity generally, not just the specific (failed) object.

trusts.q: 'Initial Failure' occurs when the purpose is impossible at the start.
trusts.exp: E.g., the charity never existed or closed before the testator's death.

trusts.q: 'Subsequent Failure' occurs after the trust has started operating.
trusts.exp: Cy-près applies automatically; funds are already dedicated to charity.

trusts.q: 'Royal Lives Clause' extends the perpetuity period.
trusts.exp: Links the 21-year period to the death of the last survivor of a royal family.

trusts.q: 'Poverty' in charity law means destitution.
trusts.exp: Re Coulthurst; it means 'going short' of normal things, not absolute destitution.

trusts.q: 'Relief of those in need' (s.3(1)(j)) requires the beneficiary to be poor.
trusts.exp: Need can arise from age, ill-health, or disability, not just financial hardship (Joseph Rowntree).

trusts.q: 'Ancillary Purpose' is a non-charitable purpose that supports the main charitable aim.
trusts.exp: E.g., a student union bar; does not invalidate charitable status.

trusts.q: 'Rule Against Remoteness of Vesting' applies to charitable trusts.
trusts.exp: Property must vest in the charity within the perpetuity period (125 years).

trusts.q: 'Human Rights' is a statutory head of charity.
trusts.exp: s.3(1)(h) Charities Act 2011; includes promotion of human rights.

trusts.q: 'Animal Welfare' trusts must benefit animals generally or specific species.
trusts.exp: Cannot be for a specific individual animal (that would be a private trust).

trusts.q: An oral declaration of a trust of land is void ab initio.
trusts.exp: s.53(1)(b) LPA 1925; it is valid but unenforceable until manifested and proved in signed writing.

trusts.q: A constructive trust of land must be evidenced in writing to be enforceable.
trusts.exp: s.53(2) LPA 1925; resulting, implied, and constructive trusts are exempt from formalities.

trusts.q: Under Milroy v Lord, equity will construe a failed gift as a self-declaration of trust to save it.
trusts.exp: Jones v Lock; equity will not assist a volunteer by perfecting an imperfect gift or changing its nature.

trusts.q: For the Re Rose exception to apply, the transferor must deliver the documents to the company registrar personally.
trusts.exp: Mascall v Mascall; it is sufficient to put the matter beyond the transferor's control (e.g., giving documents to the donee).

trusts.q: Handing a stock transfer form to the transferor's own agent puts the matter beyond their control.
trusts.exp: Re Fry; agency is revocable, so the transfer is not complete until the agent acts or documents reach the donee/registrar.

trusts.q: In Pennington v Waine, the gift was perfected because it was unconscionable for the donor to resile.
trusts.exp: The donor told the donee no further action was needed, and the donee acted to their detriment (became a director).

trusts.q: The rule in Strong v Bird applies if the donor intends to make a gift in the future.
trusts.exp: Re Freeland; there must be a continuing intention to make an *immediate* gift.

trusts.q: Strong v Bird can perfect a gift if the donee becomes the administrator of the intestate donor.
trusts.exp: Re James; the rule applies to administrators as well as executors.

trusts.q: Writing a cheque to a donee in lieu of a house demonstrates continuing intention under Strong v Bird.
trusts.exp: Re Gonin; writing the cheque showed the intention to gift the house had changed/ceased.

trusts.q: A valid Donatio Mortis Causa (DMC) requires the donor to die from the specific cause contemplated.
trusts.exp: Wilkes v Allington (general law); broadly, they must die, but the specific cause isn't strictly required if death occurs.

trusts.q: For a DMC, the donor must part with 'dominion' over the property.
trusts.exp: Sen v Headley; delivery of keys (e.g., to a deed box) can constitute constructive delivery of dominion.

trusts.q: A DMC of a house cannot be valid because land requires a deed.
trusts.exp: Sen v Headley; DMCs operate via constructive trust, overriding statutory formalities for land.

trusts.q: In Khan v Mahmood, the court held that detrimental reliance is strictly necessary for the 'unconscionable principle'.
trusts.exp: Marcus Smith J held reliance is relevant but not a strict necessity; the focus is on the donor's conscience.

trusts.q: A failed transfer on trust results in an automatic resulting trust for the settlor.
trusts.exp: If the beneficial interest is not effectively disposed of, it results back to the settlor.

trusts.q: The presumption of advancement applies when a mother transfers property to her child.
trusts.exp: Historically only Father->Child; the position for mothers is 'less clear' (Equality Act s.199 not in force).

trusts.q: A purchase money resulting trust applies to a family home acquired in joint names.
trusts.exp: Stack v Dowden; family homes are dealt with under common intention constructive trusts, not resulting trusts.

trusts.q: If A buys a car and registers it in B's name, B is presumed to hold it on trust for A.
trusts.exp: Presumed resulting trust; equity presumes bargains, not gifts (unless presumption of advancement applies).

trusts.q: The limitation period for a fraudulent breach of trust is 6 years.
trusts.exp: s.21(1) Limitation Act 1980; no limitation period applies to fraudulent breaches.

trusts.q: Under Rochefoucauld v Boustead, a trustee cannot rely on the lack of writing to keep land for themselves.
trusts.exp: Equity will not allow a statute (Statute of Frauds/LPA 1925) to be used as an instrument of fraud.

trusts.q: A valid DMC requires the donor to believe death is imminent.
trusts.exp: King v Dubrey; mere elderly age or general mortality is insufficient; death must be anticipated soon.

trusts.q: In Rahman v Hassan, handing over a Land Registry certificate was sufficient for a DMC of land.
trusts.exp: The court found valid gifts of accounts and land via delivery of documents representing title.

trusts.q: If a trust fails for uncertainty of objects, the trustee takes the property beneficially.
trusts.exp: The trustee holds on automatic resulting trust for the settlor/estate.

trusts.q: Section 53(1)(c) LPA 1925 requires dispositions of equitable interests to be in writing.
trusts.exp: Disposition of a subsisting equitable interest must be in writing signed by the disponor or agent.

trusts.q: If a father transfers money to his son, a resulting trust is presumed.
trusts.exp: Presumption of advancement applies (Father->Child), presuming a gift.

trusts.q: A self-declaration of trust requires the transfer of legal title.
trusts.exp: The settlor already holds legal title; they simply declare they now hold it as trustee.

trusts.q: 'Constitution' refers to the transfer of legal title to the trustee or donee.
trusts.exp: The trust is not 'constituted' until the property is vested in the trustee.

trusts.q: 'Donatio Mortis Causa' is a gift made in contemplation of death.
trusts.exp: A hybrid between a lifetime gift and a testamentary bequest.

trusts.q: 'Automatic Resulting Trust' arises when a trust fails and the surplus remains.
trusts.exp: The beneficial interest 'results' back to the settlor automatically.

trusts.q: 'Presumed Resulting Trust' arises from a gratuitous transfer.
trusts.exp: Equity presumes the transferor did not intend to give the property away for free.

trusts.q: 'Presumption of Advancement' presumes a gift based on relationship.
trusts.exp: Applies to Husband->Wife and Father->Child.

trusts.q: 'Fortuitous Vesting' occurs when a donee becomes the donor's personal representative.
trusts.exp: The rule in Strong v Bird; legal title vests by operation of law (administration), perfecting the gift.

trusts.q: 'Equity will not assist a volunteer' means equity will not enforce an unconstituted trust.
trusts.exp: Unless consideration was provided, equity will not compel the settlor to complete the transfer.

trusts.q: 'Dominion' refers to control over the property or indicia of title.
trusts.exp: Essential element for a valid DMC (e.g., handing over keys).

trusts.q: 'Inter Vivos' means taking place during the lifetime of the parties.
trusts.exp: Opposite of testamentary (by will).

trusts.q: 'Testamentary Trust' is created by a will.
trusts.exp: Must comply with s.9 Wills Act 1837.

trusts.q: 'Stock Transfer Form' is required to transfer shares.
trusts.exp: Along with the share certificate, sent to the company for registration.

trusts.q: 'Deed' is required to transfer legal title to land.
trusts.exp: s.52 LPA 1925; conveyance of land is void for legal estate unless made by deed.

trusts.q: 'Delivery' is required to transfer title to chattels.
trusts.exp: Re Cole; simple physical delivery with intention to give transfers ownership.

trusts.q: 'Chose in Action' is transferred by written notice to the debtor.
trusts.exp: s.136 LPA 1925; e.g., bank accounts or debts.

trusts.q: 'Unconscionability' is the trigger for a constructive trust in Pennington v Waine.
trusts.exp: If the donor's conduct makes it unconscionable to withdraw the gift, equity perfects it.

trusts.q: 'Instrument of Fraud' refers to using a statute to deny a trust.
trusts.exp: Rochefoucauld v Boustead; preventing a trustee from keeping land because the trust wasn't written.

trusts.q: 'Bare Trust' involves a trustee with no active duties.
trusts.exp: Holding title to the order of the beneficiary.

trusts.q: 'Perfecting an Imperfect Gift' is generally allowed by equity.
trusts.exp: General rule is equity will *not* perfect an imperfect gift (Milroy v Lord), subject to exceptions.

trusts.q: 'Re Rose' exception relies on the 'every effort' test.
trusts.exp: The donor must have done everything in their power to transfer title.

trusts.q: 'Loco Parentis' refers to someone taking on the role of a parent.
trusts.exp: Relevant for the presumption of advancement.

trusts.q: 'Residue' is the remainder of an estate after specific gifts/debts.
trusts.exp: If a specific trust fails, the property usually falls into residue.

trusts.q: 'Executor' is a personal representative appointed by will.
trusts.exp: They take legal title to the testator's estate.

trusts.q: 'Administrator' is a personal representative appointed by the court.
trusts.exp: Usually where there is no valid will (intestacy).

trusts.q: 'Constructive Delivery' is handing over the means of access.
trusts.exp: E.g., keys to a car or box; sufficient for DMC.

trusts.q: 'Unenforceable' means a trust is void.
trusts.exp: Unenforceable means valid but cannot be enforced in court until formalities (e.g., writing) are met.

trusts.q: The presumption of advancement applies to determine beneficial ownership of a family home between cohabitants.
trusts.exp: Jones v Kernott; resulting trusts/presumptions of advancement are displaced by the common intention constructive trust.

trusts.q: In a sole name case, the starting point is that the non-legal owner has a 50% beneficial interest.
trusts.exp: Stack v Dowden; in sole name cases, the starting point is sole beneficial ownership (equity follows the law).

trusts.q: In a joint names case, the presumption of joint beneficial ownership can be rebutted by unequal financial contributions alone.
trusts.exp: Fowler v Barron; financial contributions alone are usually insufficient; the whole course of conduct is considered.

trusts.q: Common intention can be inferred from conduct in sole name cases.
trusts.exp: Lloyds Bank v Rosset; direct contributions to the purchase price or mortgage payments can infer intention.

trusts.q: The court can impute an intention to the parties at the acquisition stage (Step 1) of a sole name claim.
trusts.exp: Barnes v Phillips; imputation is permissible only at the quantification stage, not the acquisition stage.

trusts.q: A proprietary estoppel claim requires an assurance about ownership of property.
trusts.exp: Thorner v Major; it requires an assurance about a right *in relation to* property, not strictly ownership (can be a license).

trusts.q: Detrimental reliance for a common intention constructive trust must be financial.
trusts.exp: Eves v Eves; significant physical labor (wielding a sledgehammer) can constitute detrimental reliance.

trusts.q: The 'whole course of dealing' includes advice or discussions the parties had.
trusts.exp: Stack v Dowden; Lady Hale's list includes advice/discussions as key factors.

trusts.q: An express declaration of trust in the TR1 form is conclusive of beneficial ownership.
trusts.exp: Pettitt v Pettitt / Stack v Dowden; an express declaration is conclusive unless set aside for fraud/mistake.

trusts.q: Proprietary estoppel always results in the claimant receiving the property.
trusts.exp: Guest v Guest; the remedy is the minimum to do equity/prevent unconscionability (e.g., compensation).

trusts.q: Intention can change over time ('ambulatory intention').
trusts.exp: Jones v Kernott; intentions can change, e.g., at separation, crystallizing interests differently.

trusts.q: In sole name cases, 'family home' discussions are sufficient to prove an express common intention.
trusts.exp: Lloyds Bank v Rosset; statements must be about shared *ownership*, not just shared occupation ('family home').

trusts.q: Making substantial improvements that add significant value can infer a common intention.
trusts.exp: Aspden v Elvy; substantial value-adding work can infer an intention to share ownership.

trusts.q: An excuse given by the legal owner (e.g., 'you're too young') can be evidence of common intention.
trusts.exp: Eves v Eves; such excuses imply an agreement to share but for the obstacle.

trusts.q: Paying household bills is generally sufficient to infer a common intention in sole name cases.
trusts.exp: Unless it enables the other to pay the mortgage (indirect contribution), it is usually insufficient (Rosset).

trusts.q: Rigid separation of finances was a key factor in rebutting the joint tenancy presumption in Stack v Dowden.
trusts.exp: Stack v Dowden; keeping finances strictly separate indicated an intention *not* to share equally.

trusts.q: The court can use 'fairness' as the sole basis for quantifying interests.
trusts.exp: The court looks for actual/inferred intention first; 'fairness' (imputation) is a last resort.

trusts.q: Proprietary estoppel is a cause of action, not just a defense.
trusts.exp: Unlike promissory estoppel, proprietary estoppel can be used as a sword (cause of action).

trusts.q: Unconscionability is a requirement for proprietary estoppel but not common intention constructive trusts.
trusts.exp: Constructive trusts also respond to unconscionability (denying an interest contrary to agreement/conduct).

trusts.q: A claim under the Matrimonial Causes Act 1973 applies to unmarried cohabitants.
trusts.exp: Cohabitants must rely on trusts/estoppel; the MCA 1973 applies only to married couples.

trusts.q: In Jones v Kernott, the court inferred a change of intention when Mr Kernott cashed in a life policy.
trusts.exp: Cashing in the policy and ceasing contributions signaled an end to the joint pooling of assets.

trusts.q: A proprietary estoppel remedy must match the expectation exactly.
trusts.exp: The remedy must be proportionate and avoid unconscionability; it may be less than expectation.

trusts.q: Domestic work alone (cooking/cleaning) is sufficient to infer common intention.
trusts.exp: Burns v Burns; domestic duties are generally insufficient to establish a beneficial interest.

trusts.q: In Adekunle v Ritchie, the purpose of buying the house (as a home for the mother) rebutted the joint tenancy.
trusts.exp: The primary purpose (mother's home) outweighed the joint legal title.

trusts.q: Proprietary estoppel requires a pre-existing fiduciary relationship.
trusts.exp: It requires an assurance, reliance, and detriment, not a fiduciary relationship.

trusts.q: 'Equity follows the law' is the starting presumption for joint legal owners.
trusts.exp: Joint legal tenants are presumed to be joint beneficial tenants.

trusts.q: 'Sole Legal Owner' holds the legal title alone.
trusts.exp: The presumption is they are also the sole beneficial owner.

trusts.q: 'Joint Tenants' hold the entire interest together without distinct shares.
trusts.exp: Includes the right of survivorship.

trusts.q: 'Tenants in Common' hold distinct, divisible shares.
trusts.exp: No right of survivorship; shares pass to their estate.

trusts.q: 'Common Intention Constructive Trust' is based on the shared intention of the parties.
trusts.exp: Arises to give effect to an agreement (express or inferred) acted upon to detriment.

trusts.q: 'Resulting Trust' is based on contributions to the purchase price.
trusts.exp: Generally not used for family homes anymore (Stack v Dowden).

trusts.q: 'Proprietary Estoppel' prevents a legal owner from unconscionably denying a right.
trusts.exp: Based on assurance, reliance, and detriment.

trusts.q: 'Detrimental Reliance' is conduct the claimant would not have done but for the agreement.
trusts.exp: Required for both constructive trusts and estoppel (e.g., paying mortgage, heavy DIY).

trusts.q: 'Express Common Intention' is based on explicit discussions.
trusts.exp: Spoken words about ownership (e.g., 'half yours').

trusts.q: 'Inferred Common Intention' is deduced objectively from conduct.
trusts.exp: The court looks at the 'whole course of dealing'.

trusts.q: 'Imputed Common Intention' is what reasonable people would have intended.
trusts.exp: Used as a last resort at the quantification stage.

trusts.q: 'Whole Course of Dealing' includes financial and non-financial factors.
trusts.exp: Stack v Dowden factors (children, nature of relationship, finances, etc.).

trusts.q: 'Right of Survivorship' means the interest passes to the other joint tenant on death.
trusts.exp: Applies to joint tenancies.

trusts.q: 'Severance' converts a joint tenancy into a tenancy in common.
trusts.exp: Allows a co-owner to leave their share by will.

trusts.q: 'Assurance' is a promise or representation about rights in property.
trusts.exp: The first element of proprietary estoppel.

trusts.q: 'Unconscionability' means it shocks the conscience of the court.
trusts.exp: The overarching requirement for equitable intervention.

trusts.q: 'Quantification' is the process of determining the size of the share.
trusts.exp: Step 2 in the constructive trust analysis.

trusts.q: 'Ambulatory' means the intention can change over time.
trusts.exp: Jones v Kernott; interests can 'crystallize' differently later.

trusts.q: 'TR1 Form' is used to transfer legal title to land.
trusts.exp: Contains a box to declare beneficial interests (express trust).

trusts.q: 'Excuse' cases involve a reason given for not putting a name on the title.
trusts.exp: E.g., 'too young', 'prejudice divorce'; implies agreement.

trusts.q: 'Equity' refers to the body of law supplementing the common law.
trusts.exp: Focuses on fairness and conscience.

trusts.q: 'Remedy' in estoppel is the court order to satisfy the equity.
trusts.exp: Discretionary (e.g., money, transfer of property, license).

trusts.q: 'Beneficial Interest' allows the holder to enjoy the property.
trusts.exp: Right to occupy or receive proceeds of sale.

trusts.q: 'Legal Title' is the formal paper ownership.
trusts.exp: Held by the trustees (up to 4).

trusts.q: 'Statutory Trust' arises by operation of legislation.
trusts.exp: E.g., under TLATA 1996 for co-owned land.

trusts.q: Under s.32 TA 1925 (post-2014), trustees can advance up to 100% of a beneficiary's prospective share.
trusts.exp: The Inheritance and Trustees' Powers Act 2014 removed the 50% cap for trusts created after 1 Oct 2014.

trusts.q: The statutory power of maintenance (s.31 TA 1925) applies to adult beneficiaries.
trusts.exp: It applies to minors; adults are generally entitled to income as it arises (unless the trust directs accumulation).

trusts.q: Trustees must obtain the consent of a prior life tenant to exercise the power of advancement.
trusts.exp: s.32(1)(c) TA 1925; consent is required from any person with a prior life or other interest.

trusts.q: Advancement of capital to a minor should be paid directly to the minor to ensure they receive it.
trusts.exp: Minors cannot give a valid receipt; payment should be to a parent/guardian or direct to a provider.

trusts.q: Beneficiaries can compel a trustee to retire under s.19 TLATA 1996 if they are all of full age and absolutely entitled.
trusts.exp: s.19 TLATA allows beneficiaries to direct the retirement and appointment of trustees if unanimous.

trusts.q: A trustee can be replaced under s.36(1) TA 1925 if they remain out of the UK for more than 12 months.
trusts.exp: s.36(1) lists absence from the UK for >12 months as a ground for replacement.

trusts.q: The 'benefit' for advancement is strictly limited to education or career purposes.
trusts.exp: Pilkington v IRC; 'benefit' is the 'widest possible sense', improving the material situation.

trusts.q: Trustees have a duty to ensure money advanced is applied for the stated purpose.
trusts.exp: Re Pauling's Settlement Trusts; trustees cannot simply hand over money if they suspect misuse.

trusts.q: The power of maintenance applies even if the contingent interest does not carry the intermediate income.
trusts.exp: s.31(3) TA 1925; the power applies only if the trust carries the intermediate income.

trusts.q: A trustee can retire under s.39 TA 1925 leaving only one individual trustee in office.
trusts.exp: s.39 requires that at least two individuals (or a trust corporation) remain after retirement.

trusts.q: Trustees appointed by the court under s.41 TA 1925 have fewer powers than original trustees.
trusts.exp: s.43 TA 1925; they have the same powers, authorities, and discretions as if originally appointed.

trusts.q: Existing trustees can use s.36(6) TA 1925 to appoint additional trustees.
trusts.exp: The power is vested in the person nominated or, if none, the current trustees.

trusts.q: An advancement can be made to discharge a beneficiary's moral obligation to charity.
trusts.exp: Re Clore's Settlement Trusts; benefit includes discharging moral obligations the beneficiary recognizes.

trusts.q: Income accumulated during minority under s.31 is added to capital when the beneficiary turns 18.
trusts.exp: s.31(2) TA 1925; accumulations are held as an accretion to the capital.

trusts.q: Personal representatives cannot appoint trustees if the named trustee in a will predeceases the testator.
trusts.exp: s.36(1) (via s.36(8)) allows PRs to appoint trustees if the nominated trustee dies before the testator.

trusts.q: If trustees do not exercise the power of maintenance for a minor, they must distribute the income to the parents.
trusts.exp: They must accumulate the income (invest it) if the power of maintenance is not exercised.

trusts.q: A payment under s.32 TA 1925 must be 'brought into account' at the final distribution.
trusts.exp: s.32(1)(b) TA 1925; advanced sums are deducted from the beneficiary's final share.

trusts.q: Trustees can increase the number of trustees to five using the statutory power.
trusts.exp: s.36(6) TA 1925; additional trustees cannot be appointed if it increases the number beyond four.

trusts.q: Trustees can surrender their discretion to the court if they are deadlocked.
trusts.exp: Surrendering discretion is a valid protection method in cases of deadlock or conflict.

trusts.q: Trustees can delegate their dispositive powers (e.g., choosing beneficiaries) to an agent.
trusts.exp: s.11 TA 2000; asset management is delegable, but distributive functions are not.

trusts.q: Retirement under s.39 TA 1925 requires the consent of the beneficiaries.
trusts.exp: It requires the consent by deed of the co-trustees and any person with power to appoint trustees.

trusts.q: Section 32 advancement requires the consent of beneficiaries entitled to the remainder on a gift-over.
trusts.exp: It only requires the consent of those with a *prior* interest, not subsequent/remainder interests.

trusts.q: Trustees are entitled to wait for a beneficiary to demand payment before distributing.
trusts.exp: Trustees have a positive duty to distribute income/capital as soon as it is due.

trusts.q: A Benjamin Order authorizes trustees to distribute based on a presumption (e.g., death).
trusts.exp: Re Benjamin; protects trustees from liability if the missing beneficiary later appears.

trusts.q: The power of advancement can be used to settle funds on a new trust (resettlement).
trusts.exp: Pilkington v IRC; advancement can take the form of a settlement if it benefits the beneficiary.

trusts.q: 'Dispositive Powers' relate to the distribution of trust property.
trusts.exp: E.g., Maintenance and Advancement (as opposed to Administrative powers).

trusts.q: 'Administrative Powers' relate to the management of trust property.
trusts.exp: E.g., Investment, Insurance, Delegation.

trusts.q: 'Power of Maintenance' (s.31) allows use of income for a minor.
trusts.exp: For 'maintenance, education, or benefit'.

trusts.q: 'Power of Advancement' (s.32) allows use of capital before vesting.
trusts.exp: Allows early access to capital for the beneficiary's benefit.

trusts.q: 'Accumulation' means adding unspent income to the capital.
trusts.exp: Required under s.31(2) if income is not paid out for maintenance.

trusts.q: 'Intermediate Income' is income generated by the trust fund before the capital vests.
trusts.exp: Contingent interests must carry this for s.31 to apply.

trusts.q: 'Prior Interest' refers to a beneficiary currently entitled to income (e.g., life tenant).
trusts.exp: Their consent is needed for advancement to a remainderman.

trusts.q: 'Vested in Possession' means a current right to enjoyment.
trusts.exp: E.g., the interest of a life tenant receiving income now.

trusts.q: 'Vested in Interest' means a current right to future enjoyment.
trusts.exp: E.g., a remainderman waiting for the life tenant to die.

trusts.q: 'Contingent Interest' depends on an uncertain future event.
trusts.exp: E.g., 'to X if he attains 25'.

trusts.q: 's.36 TA 1925' contains the statutory power to appoint/replace trustees.
trusts.exp: The primary mechanism for out-of-court appointments.

trusts.q: 's.19 TLATA 1996' allows beneficiaries to direct retirement/appointment.
trusts.exp: Applies where beneficiaries are sui juris and absolutely entitled.

trusts.q: 's.41 TA 1925' allows the court to appoint trustees.
trusts.exp: Used when it is 'inexpedient, difficult or impracticable' to do so otherwise.

trusts.q: 'Benjamin Order' allows distribution assuming a missing beneficiary is dead.
trusts.exp: Protects trustees from personal liability for wrongful distribution.

trusts.q: 's.27 Notice' protects trustees against claims from unknown beneficiaries.
trusts.exp: Requires advertisement in the London Gazette.

trusts.q: 'Payment into Court' (s.63) transfers funds to the court's control.
trusts.exp: A last resort for trustees wishing to be discharged when beneficiaries cannot be found.

trusts.q: 'Indemnity' allows a trustee to recover costs from the trust fund.
trusts.exp: Or from a beneficiary who instigated a breach.

trusts.q: 'Impounding' allows the court to use a beneficiary's interest to cover a breach.
trusts.exp: s.62 TA 1925; indemnifies the trustee against claims from other beneficiaries.

trusts.q: 'Lay Trustee' acts voluntarily without payment.
trusts.exp: As opposed to a professional trustee.

trusts.q: 'Professional Trustee' acts in the course of a business.
trusts.exp: Entitled to remuneration (s.29 TA 2000) and higher duty of care.

trusts.q: 'Trust Corporation' can act as a sole trustee of land.
trusts.exp: Can give valid receipt for capital money alone (unlike a sole individual).

trusts.q: 'Disclaimer' is the refusal to accept the office of trustee.
trusts.exp: A person cannot be compelled to be a trustee.

trusts.q: 'Retirement' is the discharge of a trustee from their office.
trusts.exp: Can be voluntary (s.39) or compulsory (s.19 TLATA / Court).

trusts.q: 'Removal' is the compulsory discharge of a trustee.
trusts.exp: Can be done via s.36 (if unfit/incapable) or by the Court.

trusts.q: 'Bringing into Account' deducts advanced sums from the final share.
trusts.exp: Ensures fairness among beneficiaries at the final distribution.

public_law_1.exp: Qualified.
